Author: tx
Content:
I disagree. Stick (and perfect) what you do best naturally. Yes, you don't need to have a CS degree to be good at programming, but you DO need to have a passion for it. Actually, having passion for what you do is what makes you an attractive partner to start a new business together. I personally could care less if it's a law or technology, as long as you're in love with what you're doing and it fits the objectives of the venture.

Don't force yourself to be someone you're not.

Title: Why The Community CEO Doesn't Work

Author: tx
Content:
Jesus... yet another email bashing BS. Email has always been for "old people" because it's (mostly) a working tool. Kids don't like to do work, they like to play.

It's like saying that "doing dishes is dead. leaving them dirty all over the place is the future".

Author: Kaizyn
Content:
This device is dead on arrival.

It uses the same small 6.4", 800x600 screen as the Sony Reader and has a resolution of 167 dpi. Low quality print is at 600 dpi or more.

Even if it supports PDF format, you wouldn't want to try reading pdf documents on it because you'd either have to shrink a page down to 35% or so of the full size (so it fits fully on the screen) or only render 1/3 of a page at a time.

Finally, for $400, this thing is ridiculous. It's interesting that Motorola in their low-cost cell phones (the Motorola F3) uses the e-Ink display, but these book readers are sold/marketed as premium products. Ugh.

Go into a Borders or a Sony shop to take a look at the Sony reader to get an idea of the screen size. The text rendering is impressive but not worth $300 or $400. e-Ink display technology is neat, but this first generation of products is lousy.

Author: tx
Content:
After having explored "new technologies" since my graduation in 99, I paused myself and has started moving back in time, discovering things like Lisp, Smalltalk, vim and bash. I picked up Python and rediscovered a beauty of a simple text file without XML garbage. All of that feels very "fresh" to me after years with COM-ActiveX/Win32/XML/XSLT/XPath/.NET and other "ex-new" tech.

Besides, what is "new"? MVC has been something of revelation to most web "engineers".

In fact (or maybe it comes with age) I started to dislike new stuff, like Flash/Flex/Air. I see a great danger of "web runtime" being controlled by a company. If they won't stop, Adobe will soon become "Microsoft of the Web" because they'll be controlling "Web OS". This is why I want AIR to fail and I hope that more web applications stick to HTML/CSS/JavaScript as opposed to moving to Adobe world.

For same reasons I always stayed away from Java. Same applies to Silverlight.

I do like D though (the language). But the author made two crucial mistakes that will inevitably hurt this beautiful systems programming language: he picked a name that does not work with search engines at all, and he decided to control too much - won't even let other people to distribute binaries of his compilers.

Author: thomasfl
Content: In other words. Don't save the fun for your old age. Just do it(tm). Now.

Author: tlrobinson
Content:
I plan on using the OLPC XO as an ebook reader. It's got a dual mode screen for full color indoors and grayscale in sunlight outdoors.

Since it runs Linux I'm sure it could handle pretty much any format you throw at it, given the right software.

$400 (including donation of a laptop to a child), so same price, but can do a hell of a lot more. Plus it looks cool. Plus you're donating a laptop to a child.

One week left... http://laptopgiving.org/

Author: thomasfl
Content: "I asked him what he wanted to do for his career, and he replied that he wanted to go into a particular field, but thought he should work for McKinsey for a few years first to add to his resume. To me that's like saving sex for your old age. It makes no sense."

Author: amichail
Content: Wouldn't this result in terrorists -- now US citizens -- seeking independence from the US?  It would allow them to more easily carry out bombings anywhere in the US.

Author: jey
Content:
When I first came across this I did a total double take. I can't come up with an obvious reason that this proposal is a bad idea, but it just viscerally seems like the wrong thing to do. Maybe that's just the culturally standard biases clouding my judgment though.

As for whether this is appropriate here:

"The focus of Hacker News is going to be anything that good hackers would find interesting. That includes a lot more than hacking and startups. If you had to reduce it to a sentence, the answer might be: anything that gratifies one's intellectual curiosity."

I don't mean to turn this into Hacker Politics, and maybe this is really pushing the limits of what is appropriate here, but I think this proposal is a weird and stimulating idea. I'll leave this up to the management to decide.

Author: brlewis
Content: You, I, or anyone else who attempts this, would make a sincere effort to assess their brainstorming abilities.  What we would end up with, though, is an assessment of how similar their ideas are to ours.  Ideas like ours will sound best.

Author: DanielBMarkham
Content:
I'm not sure if this was meant to be humorous or not, but it's certainly provocative. So I voted it up. I have no idea whether we can discuss mideast peace on the board in terms of hacking, but it is interesting to see it tried.

I've talked about this subject a lot on the boards. It's one of those emotionally-charged issues where it can degenerate quickly. But it's also a fascinating look into how people act to one another, and what values are important to a society. Definitely not hacking/startup related -- but interesting.
